boxes","created_by":"battalb","last_modified_by":"battalb","create_time":"2019-10-31T16:53:09Z","system_mtime":"2019-10-31T16:53:09Z","user_mtime":"2019-10-31T16:53:09Z","portion":"whole","extent_type":"cubic_feet","jsonmodel_type":"extent"}],"dates":[{"lock_version":0,"expression":"1951-2011","begin":"1951","end":"2011","created_by":"battalb","last_modified_by":"battalb","create_time":"2019-10-31T16:53:09Z","system_mtime":"2019-10-31T16:53:09Z","user_mtime":"2019-10-31T16:53:09Z","date_type":"inclusive","label":"creation","jsonmodel_type":"date"}],"external_documents":[],"rights_statements":[],"linked_agents":[{"role":"creator","relator":"aut","terms":[],"ref":"/agents/people/11810"},{"role":"creator","relator":"ctb","terms":[],"ref":"/agents/corporate_entities/28901"}],"revision_statements":[],"instances":[],"deaccessions":[],"related_accessions":[{"ref":"/repositories/2/accessions/3057"}],"classifications":[],"notes":[{"jsonmodel_type":"note_multipart","persistent_id":"f5427930361921cac16281903782b243","type":"scopecontent","subnotes":[{"jsonmodel_type":"note_text","content":"This collection holds the papers of Peter F. Geithner who served as Regional Director of Asia Programs for the Ford Foundation between 1990 and 1996. It contains both professional and personal material, and although it chiefly consists of records created during the course of Geithner’s long career in philanthropy, it was maintained by Geithner as an individual person and stored at his home in Orleans, Massachusetts. See the Other Finding Aids note to locate Ford Foundation records created by Geithner during his time as Regional Director of Asia Programs.


The collection consists of six series and seven subseries that correspond to the different organizational systems Geithner employed to arrange his papers. Although the creation dates extend from 1951 when Geithner was a student at Dartmouth College to 2011, the bulk of the collection originates from Geithner’s time as Ford’s Regional Director of Asia Programs as well as from the period following his retirement from Ford in 1996. Furthermore, there is far more professional material than personal material in the collection. It should be noted that a significant amount of the collection’s content was impacted by mold growth and removed for remediation treatment. Files with earlier creation dates and files containing personal material were among those contaminated with mold.


The majority of the collection’s material is encompassed by the first two series. These series are based on the two main arrangement schemes Geithner used to organize his records. Documents that were found in a set of boxes labeled alphabetically, A-Z comprise Series 1, and documents that were found in a set of boxes labeled numerically, 1-14D comprise Series 2. The broad scopes of these two series are represented within the titles created for them during processing. These titles are Series 1. Professional and personal files, first run and Series 2. Professional and personal files, second run. Although the later four series in the collection have more clearly defined focuses and/or internal arrangements, more substantial amounts of records on most of the topics, individuals, and organizations represented within those series are likely to be found in Series 1 and 2.


Files that document Geithner’s professional activities mostly originate from four sources: 1) His career at Ford; 2) His advisor positions at the Harvard University Asia Center and the Japan Foundation Center for Global Partnership (CGP); 3) His consultancy appointments with Ford, the Asia Pacific Philanthropy Consortium (APPC), the Rockefeller Foundation, the Sasakawa Peace Foundation (SPF), and the China Medical Board (CMB); and 4) His board and committee memberships with organizations like the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations (NCUSCR), the Institute of Current World Affairs (ICWA), the University of Pennsylvania Center for the Advanced Study of India (CASI), and the Harvard-Yenching Institute (HYI). Through his work with these organizations and his other professional contacts, he often collaborated with, served, or came into contact with a number of other civil society, research, and international cooperation groups. Some of these organizations include the Japan Center for International Cooperation (JCIE), the Commission on Human Security (CHS), the Asia Society, the Asia Foundation, the Aspen Institute, the Harvard University Ash Center for Democratic Governance and Innovation, the Council on Foundations, the American Indian Foundation (AIF), the City University of New York (CUNY) Center for Philanthropy and Civil Society, and the Asia Development Research Forum (ADRF). 


Personal materials within the collection chiefly consist of Geithner’s correspondence with family members and friends as well as a few photographs. Some celebrations and family vacation plans are documented within the files containing personal items.


The most prevalent material formats found in the collection are correspondence, reports, drafts, notes, memos, conference proceedings, agendas, schedules, pamphlets, invoices and receipts, newspaper clippings, cards, maps, and publications. Geithner also created specific files to document his business trips, and they all include copies of the travel reports he would write to log his activities. Additionally, there are several photographs and digital media items in the collection.","publish":true}],"publish":true},{"jsonmodel_type":"note_multipart","persistent_id":"d7afa420086c37934ef5d19ce0854f4b","type":"accessrestrict","rights_restriction":{"local_access_restriction_type":[]},"subnotes":[{"jsonmodel_type":"note_text","content":"Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Geithner in 2012.","publish":true}],"publish":true},{"jsonmodel_type":"note_singlepart","persistent_id":"937e9a9858b7461c6aedbdb5cdc6a784","type":"langmaterial","content":["Materials are predominately in English. However, due to the nature of Peter F. Geithner’s work in Asia, Africa, and other locations outside of the United States, there are documents in various other languages found throughout the collection. These languages include Chinese, Japanese, Vietnamese, Thai, Korean, and Hindi among others. The items in the collection that are written in these languages generally consist of conference publications and papers, promotional material for organizations in different foreign countries, and travel brochures and maps.  Oftentimes, these items include translations in one or more other languages, and English is usually one of the languages.


Travel brochures and other types of travel guide material are not described.  Most other types of documents partially written or completely written in a language other than English are noted at the file level."],"publish":true},{"jsonmodel_type":"note_multipart","persistent_id":"84f9b8433067c3d91428a529c83df351","type":"arrangement","subnotes":[{"jsonmodel_type":"note_text","content":"The collection is arranged into six series and seven subseries.


The six series derive from the original systems of arrangement used to organize the collection that were discerned during acquisition, accessioning, and processing. Peter F. Geithner appears to have used several different systems and methods for organizing his personal papers. His movements between different offices and different homes and the large timespan from which the records originate may help illuminate why the papers have various arrangement schemes. Furthermore, a significant amount of material was impacted by mold growth and removed from the collection pending mold remediation. Greater insight into Geithner’s organizational systems may be gained if the impacted material is treated and reintegrated into the collection.


The bulk of the collection’s content is contained within the first two groupings of material observed within the collection. The first grouping housed the content in a set of boxes labeled alphabetically, A-Z, while the second housed the content in a set of boxes labeled numerically, 1-14D. In regards to the A-Z boxes, the alphabetical arrangement did not reflect the organization of the files within those containers. The 1-14D boxes also did not have a consistent internal organizational structure for the files it held. Both groupings contained records created during Geithner’s time at the Ford Foundation as well as from after he retired from Ford. They also both contain professional and personal material, and they overlap in terms of creation dates. Within the finding aid, they are described as Series 1 and 2. Professional and personal files, first and second run. 


The other four groupings are smaller and have more clearly defined points of focus. Original box titles, internal arrangement schemes, and varying points of origin helped identify these groupings. They are described in the finding aid as: Series 3. Ford Foundation, Vietnam and China; Series 4. Ford Foundation, Asia-Pacific regional issues; Series 5. Professional and personal files, third run; and Series 6. Ford Foundation, trips, meetings, and conferences. Series 3 was broken into two subseries during processing in order to represent its different topical groupings and Series 5 was broken into five subseries during processing in order to represent its different topical groupings and internal organizational systems.


Original order was maintained as much as possible. Records were only moved in the few instances where reordering would support the original arrangement schemes implemented by Geithner. For instance, an original box of materials titled 14C was moved into the second series in order to maintain the numerical system of arrangement Geithner used for that segment of his materials. Likewise, another box of materials was relocated within the collection in order to reconstitute the subject files grouping found in Series 5. 


Although Geithner had created files for the majority of the documents found within the collection, there was a significant amount of loose materials in the original boxes. Files were created during processing in order to organize and properly house those records. Decisions regarding these files were based off of structural indications – uses of rubber bands or binder clips to group together items – as well as by contextual and content-centered relationships between items. 


The collection arrangement is as follows:

Series 5. Subseries 4. Philanthropic organizations and research institutions, 1995-2004

Series 6. Ford Foundation, trips, meetings, and conferences, 1989-1997","publish":true}],"publish":true},{"jsonmodel_type":"note_multipart","persistent_id":"6e818ad85abd033cf9ce8aa5defb6009","type":"bioghist","subnotes":[{"jsonmodel_type":"note_text","content":"Peter Franz Geithner (1932-2016) worked in the field of international philanthropy for more than 40 years. Between 1968 and 1996, he provided leadership for the Ford Foundation’s program activities in Asia, becoming Ford’s Regional Director of Asia Programs in 1990. After serving at Ford for almost three decades, he retired from the foundation in 1996, but remained active in philanthropic organizations and research institutions for many years after that through advisory positions, consultancy appointments, and memberships on various boards and committees. Geithner was married to Deborah Moore, and together, they had four children: Timothy, Sarah, Jonathan, and David.

Raised in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Geithner attended Northeast High School. He graduated in 1950 and then pursued his undergraduate education at Dartmouth College. Between 1954 and 1958, he served in the U.S. Navy as a naval aviator, and he earned his master’s degree from the John Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies in 1959. Prior to his work at the Ford Foundation, Geithner had jobs at Columbia Carbon International in New York City between 1959 and 1962 and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) in Zimbabwe, Zambia, and Washington D.C. between 1962 and 1968.


Geithner began his career at Ford in 1968 as Assistant/Deputy Director for India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. The Geithner family moved to New Delhi, India in order for him to take up the post. He held this position until 1973 when he and his family relocated to New York where he became Deputy Head, Office of Asia and Pacific. In 1976, he returned to Asia in order to serve as Ford’s Representative for Southeast Asia at the Bangkok, Thailand Office. This position preceded a move back to New York in 1981 when he worked as Program Officer in Charge, Developing Countries Program. He became Ford’s first representative for China in 1988 and was stationed at the foundation’s new Beijing Office. He finished his career at Ford in New York as Regional Director of Asia Programs.


Following his retirement from the Ford Foundation in 1996, Geithner became Advisor to the Asia Center at Harvard University. He also worked as an advisor for the Japan Center for Global Partnership (CGP) and had a succession of consulting appointments with the Asia Pacific Philanthropy Consortium (APPC), Ford, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Sasakawa Peace Foundation (SPF), and the China Medical Board (CMB). In addition, he served on boards and committees for organizations like the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations (NCUSCR), the Institute of Current World Affairs (ICWA), the University of Pennsylvania Center for the Advanced Study of India (CASI), and the Harvard-Yenching Institute (HYI). 


Geithner continued to focus on philanthropy and research related to Asia in his post-Ford career. However, he also participated in some philanthropic work related to Africa such as when he assisted the Rockefeller Foundation’s Nairobi, Kenya Office.


Geithner’s work in philanthropy, international relations, and development intersected with and influenced many important historical events and movements affecting the Asia-Pacific Region such as the strengthening of diplomatic ties between the United States and countries like China and Vietnam, the international response to China following the June Fourth Incident at Tiananmen Square, China’s economic development and growing place in world politics, the transfer of Hong Kong back to China, the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis, and the impact of terrorism and the War on Terror on philanthropy and international cooperation.  ","publish":true}],"publish":true},{"jsonmodel_type":"note_multipart","persistent_id":"c463a6f5abc5965ec77813ace47b28f7","type":"processinfo","subnotes":[{"jsonmodel_type":"note_text","content":"Processing Level 3: Standard Processing

"f5427930361921cac16281903782b243", "type": "scopecontent", "subnotes": [{"jsonmodel_type": "note_text", "content": "This collection holds the papers of Peter F. Geithner who served as Regional Director of Asia Programs for the Ford Foundation between 1990 and 1996. It contains both professional and personal material, and although it chiefly consists of records created during the course of Geithner’s long career in philanthropy, it was maintained by Geithner as an individual person and stored at his home in Orleans, Massachusetts. See the Other Finding Aids note to locate Ford Foundation records created by Geithner during his time as Regional Director of Asia Programs.


The collection consists of six series and seven subseries that correspond to the different organizational systems Geithner employed to arrange his papers. Although the creation dates extend from 1951 when Geithner was a student at Dartmouth College to 2011, the bulk of the collection originates from Geithner’s time as Ford’s Regional Director of Asia Programs as well as from the period following his retirement from Ford in 1996. Furthermore, there is far more professional material than personal material in the collection. It should be noted that a significant amount of the collection’s content was impacted by mold growth and removed for remediation treatment. Files with earlier creation dates and files containing personal material were among those contaminated with mold.


The majority of the collection’s material is encompassed by the first two series. These series are based on the two main arrangement schemes Geithner used to organize his records. Documents that were found in a set of boxes labeled alphabetically, A-Z comprise Series 1, and documents that were found in a set of boxes labeled numerically, 1-14D comprise Series 2. The broad scopes of these two series are represented within the titles created for them during processing. These titles are Series 1. Professional and personal files, first run and Series 2. Professional and personal files, second run. Although the later four series in the collection have more clearly defined focuses and/or internal arrangements, more substantial amounts of records on most of the topics, individuals, and organizations represented within those series are likely to be found in Series 1 and 2.


Files that document Geithner’s professional activities mostly originate from four sources: 1) His career at Ford; 2) His advisor positions at the Harvard University Asia Center and the Japan Foundation Center for Global Partnership (CGP); 3) His consultancy appointments with Ford, the Asia Pacific Philanthropy Consortium (APPC), the Rockefeller Foundation, the Sasakawa Peace Foundation (SPF), and the China Medical Board (CMB); and 4) His board and committee memberships with organizations like the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations (NCUSCR), the Institute of Current World Affairs (ICWA), the University of Pennsylvania Center for the Advanced Study of India (CASI), and the Harvard-Yenching Institute (HYI). Through his work with these organizations and his other professional contacts, he often collaborated with, served, or came into contact with a number of other civil society, research, and international cooperation groups. Some of these organizations include the Japan Center for International Cooperation (JCIE), the Commission on Human Security (CHS), the Asia Society, the Asia Foundation, the Aspen Institute, the Harvard University Ash Center for Democratic Governance and Innovation, the Council on Foundations, the American Indian Foundation (AIF), the City University of New York (CUNY) Center for Philanthropy and Civil Society, and the Asia Development Research Forum (ADRF). 


Personal materials within the collection chiefly consist of Geithner’s correspondence with family members and friends as well as a few photographs. Some celebrations and family vacation plans are documented within the files containing personal items.


The most prevalent material formats found in the collection are correspondence, reports, drafts, notes, memos, conference proceedings, agendas, schedules, pamphlets, invoices and receipts, newspaper clippings, cards, maps, and publications. Geithner also created specific files to document his business trips, and they all include copies of the travel reports he would write to log his activities. Additionally, there are several photographs and digital media items in the collection.", "publish": true}], "publish": true}, {"jsonmodel_type": "note_multipart", "persistent_id": "d7afa420086c37934ef5d19ce0854f4b", "type": "accessrestrict", "rights_restriction": {"local_access_restriction_type": []}, "subnotes": [{"jsonmodel_type": "note_text", "content": "Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. He also worked as an advisor for the Japan Center for Global Partnership (CGP) and had a succession of consulting appointments with the Asia Pacific Philanthropy Consortium (APPC), Ford, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Sasakawa Peace Foundation (SPF), and the China Medical Board (CMB). In addition, he served on boards and committees for organizations like the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations (NCUSCR), the Institute of Current World Affairs (ICWA), the University of Pennsylvania Center for the Advanced Study of India (CASI), and the Harvard-Yenching Institute (HYI). 


Geithner continued to focus on philanthropy and research related to Asia in his post-Ford career. However, he also participated in some philanthropic work related to Africa such as when he assisted the Rockefeller Foundation’s Nairobi, Kenya Office.


Geithner’s work in philanthropy, international relations, and development intersected with and influenced many important historical events and movements affecting the Asia-Pacific Region such as the strengthening of diplomatic ties between the United States and countries like China and Vietnam, the international response to China following the June Fourth Incident at Tiananmen Square, China’s economic development and growing place in world politics, the transfer of Hong Kong back to China, the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis, and the impact of terrorism and the War on Terror on philanthropy and international cooperation. Communications Office","publish":true}],"publish":true},{"jsonmodel_type":"note_multipart","persistent_id":"bf6f4b070a1be6dd23dc979e3853a8ac","type":"bioghist","subnotes":[{"jsonmodel_type":"note_text","content":"The China Medical Board was established in November, 1914 as a division of The Rockefeller Foundation for the purpose of developing modern medicine in China.  Its program was based on the recommendations of the China Medical Commission which consisted of Harry Pratt Judson, Roger S. Greene and Francis W. Peabody.  The group traveled to China, the Philippines and Japan in the spring of 1914 visiting medical schools, mission hospitals and colleges and universities.  The plan which was adopted was to develop two medical schools, strengthen mission and other hospitals and provide scholarships for Chinese and foreign doctors and nurses.

Wallace Buttrick was Director from 1914-1918, while Roger Greene was the Resident Director in China.  On Mr. Buttrick's retirement, George E. Vincent became Director.  In 1922 Dr. Vincent became General Director while Mr. Green became Director and Henry S. Houghton assumed the position of Acting Resident Director.  Mr. Green became General Director in 1925 and N. Gist Gee joined the staff in 1926 as advisor in premedical education.

Peking and Shanghai were chosen as sites of support because two relatively strong medical schools already existed there.  In the autumn of 1951 Wallace Buttrick, William H. Welch, Simon Flexner and Frederick L. Gates traveled to China to develop a program for the Peking school.  The Union Medical College of Peking was supported by several missionary boards, hence the word union.  It was purchased by the China Medical Board in 1915 and chartered by the Regents of the State of New York in 1916.  Franklin C. McLean was elected Head of the College.  Trustees represented both The Rockefeller Foundation and the missionary boards.  A construction program was started in 1916, premedical classes began in 1917 and the College opened in 1919.  Buildings were dedicated in 1921.

The same type of program was assumed for the Harvard Medical School in Shanghai, and trustees were incorporated in 1917 under a charter of the University of the State of New York.  However, building was delayed until the completion of the Peking complex. Because the war increased the difficulties of getting materials to China and because of exchange and price spiral, the Peking construction program was lengthened and costs became prohibitive.  In [1917] plans for the Shanghai school were dropped.

The functions of the China Medical Board were transferred in 1927 to the Division of Medical Education of The Rockefeller Foundation and in November, 1928, the land and buildings of the Peking Union Medical College were transferred to the China Medical Board, Incorporated, an independent organization.


The Rockefeller Foundation:

The Rockefeller Foundation was established by act of the New York State Legislature approved by the Governor on May 14, 1913, "to promote the well-being of mankind throughout the world." Between 1913 and 1928 the China Medical Board, the International Health Board, and the Division of Medical Education functioned as divisions of the Foundation, concentrating on the administration of programs in public health and medical education. A Division of Studies was created in 1923 to handle projects outside the medical field. These early years were experimental as the new foundation studied the methods of philanthropy and explored its relationships with other Rockefeller boards.

Although the Rockefeller Foundation is the largest and best known philanthropy founded by the Rockefeller family, it was neither the first nor the last to be established. The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (1901), the General Education Board (1902), the Rockefeller Sanitary Commission for the Eradication of Hookworm Disease (1909), and the Bureau of Social Hygiene (1911) all existed earlier. When the Foundation was created, the Sanitary Commission was disbanded. After the establishment of the Foundation, the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial (1918) and the International Education Board (1923) were created.

The Rockefeller boards and their programs were reconsidered and reorganized in 1927-1928 in order to avoid overlapping programs. The International Health Board of the Foundation was disbanded and an International Health Division was organized. The China Medical Board, Inc., was established as a separately incorporated institution, and the China Medical Board of the Foundation ceased to exist. The Division of Studies was dropped and the Division of Medical Education was phased out. The Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial was combined with the Foundation and the Spelman Fund of New York was chartered to continue activities of the LSRM that were not absorbed by the Foundation. The International Education Board was disbanded.

As a result of this reorganization, the Foundation adopted a program which included public health work (administered by the IHD), the advancement of knowledge in the medical and natural sciences (in part taken over from the IEB), the social sciences (formerly the field of the LSRM), and the humanities and arts (shared with the GEB). The Rockefeller Institute and the Bureau of Social Hygiene were not affected by the reorganization. The program adopted by the Foundation at this time remained basically the same for the next twenty years.

As its files accumulated, the Foundation maintained a card index recording the names of institutional and individual grantees and correspondents. A microfilm copy of this index is available at the Archive Center.","publish":true}],"publish":true},{"jsonmodel_type":"note_multipart","persistent_id":"b08667436e0f073deff4e19831019e92","type":"prefercite","subnotes":[{"jsonmodel_type":"note_text","content":"Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at <extref href="http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php">http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php</extref>","publish":true}],"publish":true},{"jsonmodel_type":"note_multipart","persistent_id":"aeb890cda4e31c404e5bbfa84d775090","type":"fileplan","subnotes":[{"jsonmodel_type":"note_text","content":"RG 4

As a result of this reorganization, the Foundation adopted a program which included public health work (administered by the IHD), the advancement of knowledge in the medical and natural sciences (in part taken over from the IEB), the social sciences (formerly the field of the LSRM), and the humanities and arts (shared with the GEB). The Rockefeller Institute and the Bureau of Social Hygiene were not affected by the reorganization. The program adopted by the Foundation at this time remained basically the same for the next twenty years.

As its files accumulated, the Foundation maintained a card index recording the names of institutional and individual grantees and correspondents. A microfilm copy of this index is available at the Archive Center.", "publish": true}], "publish": true}, {"jsonmodel_type": "note_multipart", "persistent_id": "b08667436e0f073deff4e19831019e92", "type": "prefercite", "subnotes": [{"jsonmodel_type": "note_text", "content": "Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at <extref href="http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php">http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php</extref>", "publish": true}], "publish": true}, {"jsonmodel_type": "note_multipart", "persistent_id": "aeb890cda4e31c404e5bbfa84d775090", "type": "fileplan", "subnotes": [{"jsonmodel_type": "note_text", "content": "RG 4
